In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: Wich that I help my fadir͗e for to stele
And good lemman God the save and kepe
And with that word she gan for to wepe
Aleyn vp rist and thoght or it dawe
I wol go crepe in be my felawe
And felt the Cradil with his hond a none
Be God thoght he al wrong have I gone
Myn hede is toty of my swynk al nyght
That makith me that I go nat a right
I woot wele be the cradil I have mys go
Her͗e lijth the myller͗e and his wyfe also
And forth he goith a twenty dewil wey
Vnto the bed ther͗e as the myller lay
He went have cropyn by his felowe Iohn
And by the myller he crepith in a non̄
He kauȝt him be the nek and soft spak
He seid þowe Iohn thowe swynyshede a wake
For Cristis soule and here a nobil game
For by that lord that callid is seynt Iame
As I have thryis in this short nyght
Swywyd the myller͗e his doghter bolt vp right
Whylis thowe hast as a coward ben̄ a gast
Ye fals harlot quod the myller hast
A fals treytour͗e a fals clerk seid he
Thowe shalt be dede be goddis dignyte
Who dare be so bold for to disperage
My doghter that is com of such lynage
And by the throte bol he caght aleyn̄
And he hem dispitously a gayn̄
And on the nose he smote him with his fist
Doun̄ ran the blode streme oppon his brest
And in the flore with nose and mowth to broke
They walowid as done to piggis in a poke
And vp they goon and doun a geyn a none
Tyl that the myller͗e stombelit atta stone
And doun̄ he fil bakward on his wyfe
That wist no thing of that nyse stryfe
For she was ful of slepe a lityl wigh
With Iohn the clerk that wakid hath al nyght
And with the fal out of her͗e slepe she breyd
Help holy Cros of bromh~olm she seyd
In manus tuas to the lord I cal
A wake Symond the fynd ys on vs fal
Myn hert is brokyn help I am but dede
Ther͗e lijth on my wombe and on myn̄ hede
Help Symkyn for the fals clerkis fight
This Iohn stert vp as sone as euyr he myght
And graspid by the wallis to and fro
To fynd a staf and she stert vp also
And knewe the estis bet than did þis Iohn
And by the wal a staf she fond a none
And saw a litil shymyryng of a light
For atta hole in shone the mone light
And by that light she sawe hem both to
But sikirly she ne wist who was who
And as she sawe a white in her͗e ye
And when she gan the white þing a spy
She wend the Clerk had werid a voluper͗e
And with the stafe she drowe ay nere and nere
And wend to have hit this Aleyn atte ful
And smote the myller on the pillid skul
And doun̄ he goith and crijd harowe I dy
These Clerkis bete him wele and lete him ly
And graythed hem and toke her͗e korn̄ a none
And eke her͗e mele and on her͗e wey they gone
And atte myl dor yit they toke her kake
Of half a busshel flour͗e wele I bake
Thus is the prowd myller͗e wel I bete
And hath I lost the gryndyng of his whete
And paid for the sowper͗e euerydele
Of Aleyn and Iohn that bete him wele
His wyfe is swywid and þe doghter als
Lo such it is a myller for to be fals
And ther͗e for this proverbe is ful soth
Him thar͗e nat wene wele that ewil doith
A gyler͗e shal e vir͗e e vir͗e evir͗e begylid b
And God that sittith hy in mageste
Save al this compane grete and smale
Thus have I quyt the Myller͗e his tale
Here endith the Reve his tale
Here beginnyth the Koke his Prollog
Te koke of london̄ while þe Reve spak
For Ioy he thoght he clawid him on þe bak
Aha quod he for Cristis own̄ passioun̄
This Myller͗e hath a sharp conclucioun
Oppon his argument of herbegage
Wele seyd Salamon in his langage
Ne prese nat euery man in to thyn howse
For herburghyng be nyght is perlowse
Wele oght a man a vysid for to be
Whom that he bryng in to his pryvite
I pray to God so yeve me sorowe and care
Syn ewyr͗e that I hight hoge of ware
Herd I Myller͗e bet I set a werk
He had a Iape of malice in the derk
But God for bede þat wee styntyn here
And þerfore yf yee wowch save to here
A tale of me that am a pore man
I wol yewe tel as wel as ewir I can̄
A litil Iape that fil in our͗e Cete
Our͗e Ost answerd and seid I grᵃaunnt it the
Nowe tel on Roger͗e loke that it be good
For many a pasty hast þowe lete blode
And many a Iak of dowir͗e hast þowe sold
That hathe be twyis hote and twyis cold
Of many a pylgrym hast þowe Cristis Curs
For yit of thy persely they fare the wors
Nowe tel on gentil Roger͗e be thy name
But I prey the be nat wroth for game
A man may sey ful sothe in game and pley
Thowe seyst ful sothe seid Roger͗e be my fe
But sooth pley quade pley as þe Flemyng seith
And ther͗e for harry bayly be thy feith
Be thowe nat wroth or we departyn̄ here
Thogh that my tale be of an hostelere
But nethirles I wol nat tel hit yit
But or we depart I wis þowe shalt be quyt
And ther͗e with al he lowȝe and made chere
And seid his tale as yee shul aftir͗e here
Here endith the Koke his prollog
And here begynnyth his tale
A prentise whylom dwellid in this Cete
Of a craft of vittellers was he
A gaylard he was as Goldsmyth in þe shawe
Broun as a bery and a ꝓpropir short felawe
With lokkis blak I kembit ful fetously
Daunce he cowd þat wel and Iolely
For he was clepid Perkyn reveloure
He was as ful of love and paramour

div.ab:
(base) for as muche thanne as reson is rebel to god therfore is man worthy to haue sorwe and
to be deed

(base) this suffred oure lord Ihesu crist for man after that he
hadde be bitraysed of his disciple and destreyned and bounde so that
the blood brast out at euery nayl of hise handes as seith Seint
Augustyn

(base) And forther ouer for as muchel as reson of man ne
wol nat daunte sensualitee whan it may therfore is man worthy to han shame and this suffrede oure lord Ihesu crist for man
whan they spette in his visage

(base) and forther ouer for as muche
thanne as the kaytif body of man is rebel bothe to resoun and to
sensualitee therfore is it worthy the deeth

(base) and this suffred oure
lord Ihesu crist for man vp on the croys where as ther nas no part
of his body free with oute gret peyne and bitter passioun

(base) and al this
suffred Ihesu crist that neuere forfeted to muchel am I peyned for the
thynges that I neuere deserued and to muche defouled for shendshipe that man is worthy to haue

(base) And therfore may the synful
man wel seye as seith Seint Bernard Acursed be the bitternesse
of my synne for which ther moste be suffred so muche bitternesse

(base) for certes after the diuerse discordaunces of oure wikkednesses was
the passioun of Ihesu crist ordeyned in diuerse thynges

(base) As thus
Certes synful mannes soule is bitraysed of the deuel by coueitise of temporel prosperitee and scorned by deceyte whan he cheseth
flesshly delices and yet is it tormented by inpacience of Aduersitee and byspet by seruage and subieccioun of synne and atte laste
it is slayn fynally

(base) for this desordenaunce of synful man was
Ihesu crist first bitraysed and after that was he bownde that cam
for to vnbynde vs of synne and of peyne
(base) thanne was he biscorned that oonly sholde ben honoured in alle thynges of alle thynges

(base) thanne was his visage that oghte be desired to be seyn of all
mankynde in which visage Angels desiren to looke vileynsly
bispet

(base) thanne was he skourged that no thyng hadde agilt and
fynally thanne was he crucefied and slayn

(base) thanne was acompli ced the word of Ysaie he was wounded for oure mysdedes and
defouled by oure felonyes

(base) Now sith that Ihesu crist took vp on
hym self the peyne of alle oure wikkednesses muchel oghte
synful man wepe and biwayle that for hise synnes goddes sone
of heuene sholde al this peyne endure

(base) The vjthe thyng that
oghte moeue a man to Contricioun is the hope of iij thynges
that is to seyn foryeuenesse of synne and the

wel for to do and the glorie of heuene with which god shal gerdone man for hise goode dedes

yeueth vs thise yiftes of his largesse and of his souereyn bountee
therfore is he clepid Ihesus Nazarenus rex Iudeorum

(base) Ihesu is for
to seyn Saueour or Sauacioun on whom men shal hope to haue foryifnesse of synnes which that is proprely Sauacion of synnes

(base) and therfore seyde the Aungel to Ioseph thow shalt clepe
his name Ihesus that shal saue his peple of hire synnes

(base) And heer
of seith Seint Peter ther is noon oother name vnder heuene that is yeue to any man by which a man may be saued but
oonly Ihesus

(base) Nazarenus is as muche for to seye as florissynge
In which a man shal hope that he that yeueth hym remissioun of
synnes shal yeue hym eek grace wel to do for in the flour is
hope of fruyt in tyme comynge and in foryifnesse of synnes
hope of grace wel to do

(base) I was at the dore of thyn herte seith
Ihesus and clepede for to entre he that opneth to me shal haue foryifnesse of synne

(base) I wol entre in to hym by my grace and sowpe
with hym by the goode werkes that he shal doon whiche werkes
ben the foode of god and he shal sowpe with me by the grete
ioye that I shal yeue hym

(base) thus shal man hope that for hise
werkes of penance god shal yeue hym his regne as he by
heteth hym in the gospel

(base) Now shal man vnderstonde
in which manere shal ben his contricioun I seye that it shal
ben vniuersal and total this is to seyn a man shal be verray repentaunt for alle hise synnes that he hath doon in delit of his thoght for delit is ful perilous
(base) for ther ben two manere of consentynges that oon of hem is clepid consentynge of affeccion whan a man is moeued to do synne and thanne deliteth hym longe for to thynke on that synne

(base) and his
reson aperceyueth wel that it is synne agayns the lawe of god
and yet his resoun refreyneth nat his fool delit or talent
though he seeth wel apertly that it is agayns the reuerence
of god al though his resoun ne consente nat to doon the
synne in dede

(base) yet seyn somme doctours that swich delit that dwelleth
longe it is ful perilous al be neuer so lite

(base) and also a man sholde sorwe namely for al that euere he hath desired agayn the
lawe of god with parfit consentynge of his resoun for ther of is
no doute that it is dedly synne in the consentynge

(base) for certes ther
is no dedly synne that it nas first in mannes thoght and after
that

and in verray feith and that men preye to god ordinatly and discreetly

dynatly and discreetly and deuoutly and alwey a man schal pt

(base) After this thou shalt vnderstonde that bodily
peyne stant in wakynge for Ihesu crist seith waketh and preyeth

also that fastynge stant in thre thynges In forberynge of bodily mete and drynke and in forberynge of worldly Iolitee and in forberynge
of deedly synne this is to seyn that a man shal kepen hym fro

(base) And thou shalt vnderstanden
eek that god ordeyned fastynge and to fastynge apertenen iiij thinges

(base) Largenesse to poure folk gladnesse of herte espiritueel nat to been angry ne anoyed ne grucche for he fasteth and also resonable houre for to
ete by mesure that is for to seyn a man shal nat ete in vntyme ne

(base) Thanne shaltow vnderstonde that bodily peyne stant in disciplyne or techynge by

or of stamyn or of haubergeons on hir naked flessh for cristes sake
and swiche manere penances

(base) but war thee wel that swiche manere
penaunces on thy flessh ne make thee nat or angry or anoyed of thy
self for bettre is to caste awey thyn heyre than for to caste awey the
sikernesse of Ihesu crist

(base) And therfore seith seint Paul Clothe yow
as they that been chosen of god in herte of Misericorde debonairetee

yerdes in knelynges in tribulacions
(base) in suffrynge paciently wronges that been doon to thee and eek in pacient suffraunce of maladies or lesynge of worldly catel or of wyf or of child or othere freendes

(base) Thanne shalt

ow vnderstonde whiche thynges destourben

the shame that a man hath to shryuen hym and namely thise
